title: Know Your Mindsets
text:
Prologue
Welcome to Know Your Mindsets: An Interactive Guide for PH 322 — Communicating Health Information in the Digital Age at Binghamton University. This course is part of the public health minor, which is offered by Decker College’s Division of Public Health.

title: Know Your Mindsets
text:
About the Course
Where did you get that information? Can I trust them? How do I know they’re not lying to me? We navigate questions like these every day — when reading the news, scrolling social media, or deciding whether to follow a doctor’s advice. PH 322 — Communicating Health Information in the Digital Age explores these real-world challenges by introducing the theories, strategies, and tools used to design and evaluate health messages across media platforms. Through hands-on projects and critical analysis, you will learn how to create messages that are accurate, persuasive, culturally relevant, and ethically grounded — while also learning how to recognize misinformation and manipulation.
At its core, health communication is about more than sending messages — it is about achieving shared understanding. Communication is the process through which we exchange information, but shared understanding is the outcome we seek. To achieve shared understanding, we must know ourselves and know others so that we can send and receive health messages effectively. This guide is designed to help you do both: by examining your own mindsets, beliefs, and orientations, you develop the self-awareness needed to connect with diverse audiences and craft messages that truly resonate.

Each week follows a consistent rhythm: you begin with the reading to build foundational knowledge, then complete a psychographic self-assessment that connects course concepts to your own beliefs and orientations. Monday lectures introduce health communication theory, Wednesday case studies apply those ideas through real-world examples and hands-on activities, and campaign worksheets guide you in building a semester-long health communication campaign from concept to completion. This structure ensures that you are not just learning about health communication — you are actively doing it.

title: Know Your Mindsets
text:
Psychographics and Self-Awareness
A central feature of this course is the emphasis on psychographics — the psychological beliefs, values, motivations, and orientations that shape how people receive, interpret, and respond to health messages. Unlike demographics (age, gender, income), psychographics capture why people think and behave the way they do. In health communication, understanding your audience’s psychographic profile is essential for designing messages that resonate.
At the start of the semester, you completed a comprehensive Anonymous Beliefs Survey measuring key psychographic constructs. This guide presents your individual scores alongside the class distribution so you can reflect on who you are as a health communicator. Effective health communicators are aware of their own knowledge, beliefs, skills, identities, and biases (Eurich, 2017). By examining your own psychographic profile, you will develop the meta-cognitive awareness needed to:

Understand how your motivational orientation, moral foundations, cultural values, health beliefs, and social locations influence your receptivity to health messages
Recognize how your beliefs differ from — or align with — those of your peers and the broader public
Apply self-knowledge to design more effective, audience-centered health communication campaigns

The next chapter explains how this guide is organized and how to find and interpret your scores.

title: 1  A Guide for You
text:
1.2 How to Use Your Mindsets
Throughout this guide, you will encounter color-coded callout boxes that connect your psychographic scores to different components of the course:






ImportantPsychographics



Red callout boxes highlight connections to your psychographic self-assessments. We complete these assessments to learn more about ourselves and build self-awareness — the foundation for effective health communication.








TipCase Studies



Green callout boxes highlight connections to case study analysis. Each week, we consider how these mindsets influence our responses during case study discussions and real-world examples.








WarningHealth Campaign



Orange callout boxes highlight connections to your health communication campaign. We consider how these mindsets influence our ability to create effective health messages and the ways other people will receive those messages.

title: 1  A Guide for You
text:
1.3 How to Find Your Scores
At the end of the anonymous survey, you created a password (5 letters + 4 numbers). Each chapter contains a table where you can look up your password to find your composite scores on that week’s measures.






NoteSave Your Password



Your password is the key to accessing your individual scores throughout the semester. Keep it saved in your phone notes or on a sticky note. If you want to replace your current password with a new password, contact Dr. Shane McCarty.

title: 1  A Guide for You
text:
1.4 How to Interpret Your Scores
Each measure in this guide produces a composite score — a single number that summarizes your responses on a set of related survey questions. To calculate it, we take all of your answers within a subscale and average them together. For example, if a subscale has 5 questions and you answered 3, 4, 5, 4, and 4, your composite score would be 4.0. This gives you one easy-to-read number instead of having to interpret each question individually.
Here is how to interpret your results:

Find your score in the password lookup table
Locate your score on the class density plot — the dashed vertical lines show the 33rd and 67th percentiles
Compare where you fall relative to the distribution: Are you low, mid, or high on this measure?
Reflect on what your score means for how you receive and design health messages







NoteThere Are No Right or Wrong Scores



These measures capture a range of psychological beliefs and orientations. The purpose is self-awareness, not evaluation. Different mindsets bring different strengths to health communication.

title: 1  A Guide for You
text:
1.5 About the Data
The data in this guide comes from the Anonymous Beliefs Survey completed by students in PH322 (Communicating Health Information) and ANTH206 (Community Health Research Methods) in Spring 2026. By combining data from both classes, we create a larger reference sample for you to compare your scores against.

All participants: Visualizations show the full sample from both classes
PH322 students: Your password lookup tables show scores for PH322 students specifically
Composite scores: Calculated as the average of your responses to the items within each subscale (after adjusting any reverse-coded items so that all questions point in the same direction)

title: 2  Thinking Preferences
text:
2.1 The Four Thinking Preferences
This chapter introduces the concept of thinking preferences — the idea that people tend to favor certain cognitive approaches when solving problems, communicating, and making decisions. Understanding your own thinking preferences is the first step toward becoming an effective health communicator, because it helps you recognize your natural strengths, your blind spots, and how to connect with audiences who think differently than you do.
Research on cognitive styles and thinking preferences suggests that people tend to favor one or more of four broad thinking orientations. These are not rigid categories — most people use all four at different times — but each of us has natural tendencies that shape how we approach tasks, process information, and communicate with others.

title: 2  Thinking Preferences
text:
2.1.1 Analytical Thinking
People who favor analytical thinking are drawn to data, logic, and evidence. They prefer to work with facts, numbers, and well-reasoned arguments. In health communication, analytical thinkers tend to focus on the strength of the evidence base, the precision of statistical claims, and the logical structure of an argument.
Strengths in health communication: Evaluating research quality, identifying logical fallacies in health claims, crafting evidence-based messages


2.1.2 Structural Thinking
People who favor structural thinking prefer organization, planning, and reliability. They value clear processes, step-by-step approaches, and attention to detail. In health communication, structural thinkers excel at campaign planning, implementation timelines, and ensuring messages are consistent and well-organized.
Strengths in health communication: Developing systematic campaign plans, creating consistent messaging frameworks, managing project timelines and deliverables


2.1.3 Social Thinking
People who favor social thinking are attuned to emotions, relationships, and interpersonal dynamics. They naturally consider how people feel, how groups interact, and how messages affect individuals. In health communication, social thinkers are often skilled at understanding audience needs, building trust, and crafting messages that resonate emotionally.
Strengths in health communication: Understanding audience perspectives, building community engagement, designing empathetic and culturally sensitive messages


2.1.4 Conceptual Thinking
People who favor conceptual thinking are drawn to big-picture ideas, innovation, and creative possibilities. They enjoy brainstorming, imagining new approaches, and thinking about how things could be different. In health communication, conceptual thinkers often generate novel campaign ideas, identify unexpected connections, and push creative boundaries.
Strengths in health communication: Generating creative campaign concepts, identifying innovative channels and formats, connecting health topics to broader cultural narratives

title: 2  Thinking Preferences
section: 2.2 Why Thinking Preferences Matter for Health Communication
text:
2.2 Why Thinking Preferences Matter for Health Communication
No single thinking preference is better than another — effective health communication requires all four. A successful health campaign needs:

Analytical thinking to ensure the message is grounded in evidence
Structural thinking to execute the campaign plan systematically
Social thinking to connect with audiences on a human level
Conceptual thinking to create messages that capture attention and inspire change

By understanding your own preferences, you can:

Leverage your strengths — lean into your natural style when it serves the task
Compensate for gaps — deliberately engage less-preferred styles when needed
Collaborate more effectively — value teammates whose preferences complement yours
Design for diverse audiences — create campaigns that appeal to multiple thinking styles

title: 2  Thinking Preferences
text:
2.3 Learn More
The concept of thinking preferences has been explored through several frameworks in psychology and organizational development. Two widely-used models include:

Herrmann Brain Dominance Instrument (HBDI): Developed by Ned Herrmann, this model maps thinking preferences across four quadrants. Learn more at Herrmann Global.
Emergenetics: Developed by Geil Browning, this profile measures thinking preferences alongside behavioral attributes. Learn more at Emergenetics.

Both frameworks highlight that people differ in how they naturally approach thinking, and that awareness of these differences is key to effective communication and teamwork.






NoteReflect on Your Thinking Preferences



As you move through the rest of this guide, consider which thinking preference you rely on most when interpreting your scores. Do you focus on the numbers (analytical)? The patterns (structural)? How the results make you feel (social)? Or the bigger implications (conceptual)?

title: 3  Regulatory Focus
text:
3.1 Regulatory Focus Questionnaire
This chapter examines three measures of regulatory focus — motivational orientations that shape whether you focus on pursuing positive outcomes (promotion) or avoiding negative outcomes (prevention). Understanding your regulatory focus orientation is foundational to health communication because it directly influences how you frame health messages and how those messages are received by different audiences.

title: 3  Regulatory Focus
text:
Constructs
The Regulatory Focus Questionnaire (RFQ; Higgins et al., 2001) measures whether your general behavioral style is driven by promotion or prevention.

Promotion Focus: An eagerness-based orientation toward achieving gains, pursuing ideals, and accomplishing aspirations
Prevention Focus: A vigilance-based orientation toward avoiding losses, fulfilling duties, and meeting obligations



Measures
The RFQ contains 11 items (6 promotion, 5 prevention) rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Never or Seldom, 2 = Rarely, 3 = Sometimes, 4 = Often, 5 = Very Often. Higher scores indicate a stronger orientation toward that focus.
Example items:

Promotion: “How often have you accomplished things that got you ‘psyched’ to work even harder?”
Prevention: “Compared to most people, are you typically unable to get what you want out of life?” (reverse-scored)



Your Scores
Find your password below to see your Regulatory Focus Questionnaire scores.






NoteA Note about Passwords



A few students provided identifying passwords. Those passwords were changed to use “health” and retained the original numbers in your password. You should be able to identify your new password now. If you cannot find your password, contact Dr. Shane McCarty.

title: 3  Regulatory Focus
text:
3.2 Health Regulatory Focus Scale

Constructs
The Health Regulatory Focus Scale (HRFS; Ferrer et al., 2017) measures whether you approach your own health with a health promotion focus or health prevention focus orientation.

Health Promotion Focus: Striving toward ideal health, feeling accomplished by healthy behaviors, and admiring healthy people
Health Prevention Focus: Worrying about illness, feeling anxious about health obligations, and fearing future health problems



Measures
The HRFS contains 12 items (6 promotion, 6 prevention) rated on a 6-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Slightly Agree, 5 = Agree, 6 = Strongly Agree. Higher scores indicate a stronger health-specific focus.
Example items:

Health Promotion: “I frequently imagine how I can achieve a state of ‘ideal health.’”
Health Prevention: “I often worry that I am not doing the best I can to improve my health.”

title: 3  Regulatory Focus
text:
3.3 Prosocial Regulatory Focus Scale

Constructs
The Prosocial Regulatory Focus Scale (McCarty et al., 2026) measures whether your prosocial motivation is oriented toward promoting care for others or preventing harm to others.

Promoting Care: Focusing on making positive impacts, uplifting others, and helping people achieve well-being
Preventing Harm: Focusing on stopping harmful actions, taking preventive action, and protecting people from threats



Measures
The scale contains 10 items (5 promoting care, 5 preventing harm) rated on a 6-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Slightly Agree, 5 = Agree, 6 = Strongly Agree. Higher scores indicate a stronger prosocial orientation in that direction.
Example items:

Promoting Care: “I typically focus on making a positive impact on people.”
Preventing Harm: “I am generally good at stopping harmful actions from happening to people.”

title: 4  Health Literacy
text:
4.1 Health Literacy Scale
This chapter focuses on health literacy — your ability to find, understand, evaluate, and use health information. Health literacy is a critical determinant of health communication effectiveness because it shapes how audiences engage with health messages, navigate health systems, and make informed decisions.

title: 4  Health Literacy
text:
Constructs
The Health Literacy Scale (adapted from the European Health Literacy Survey (HLS-EU)) measures your self-assessed ability to navigate health information. Health literacy encompasses the knowledge, motivation, and competencies needed to access, understand, appraise, and apply health information in everyday life.


Measures
The scale contains 8 items rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Very Bad, 2 = Bad, 3 = Moderate, 4 = Good, 5 = Very Good. Higher scores indicate higher self-reported health literacy. Participants who selected “I do not make use of this kind of information” are coded as missing.
Example items:

“How well do you understand instruction leaflets for medication?”
“When I have questions on diseases or complaints, I know where I can find information on these issues.”

title: 5  Psychological Beliefs
text:
5.1 Free Will & Determinism (FAD-Plus)
This chapter explores five measures of psychological beliefs that shape how people think about control, agency, self-efficacy, and information seeking. These beliefs are critical for health communication because they influence whether audiences feel empowered to change their behavior, whether they seek or avoid health information, and what types of behavior change strategies are most effective.

title: 5  Psychological Beliefs
text:
Constructs
The FAD-Plus (Paulhus & Carey, 2011) measures lay beliefs about free will and determinism across four subscales:

Free Will: Belief that people have complete control over their decisions and are responsible for their actions
Scientific Determinism: Belief that biology, genetics, environment, and science determine behavior
Fatalistic Determinism: Belief that fate, destiny, and mysterious forces control life outcomes
Unpredictability: Belief that life is random, unpredictable, and governed by chance



Measures
The FAD-Plus contains 27 items across four subscales (Free Will: 7 items; Scientific Determinism: 7 items; Fatalistic Determinism: 5 items; Unpredictability: 8 items) rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree. Higher scores indicate stronger endorsement of that belief.
Example items:

Free Will: “People have complete control over the decisions they make.”
Scientific Determinism: “People’s biological makeup determines their talents and personality.”
Fatalistic Determinism: “I believe that the future has already been determined by fate.”
Unpredictability: “Chance events seem to be the major cause of human history.”

title: 5  Psychological Beliefs
text:
5.2 Health Self-Efficacy

Constructs
The Health Self-Efficacy Scales (Schwarzer & Renner, 2000) measure your confidence in maintaining healthy behaviors despite common barriers.

Nutrition Self-Efficacy: Your confidence in sticking to healthful foods despite barriers such as needing new routines, repeated attempts, rethinking your diet, lack of support, or needing a detailed plan
Physical Exercise Self-Efficacy: Your confidence in exercising despite barriers such as worries, depression, tension, tiredness, or being busy



Measures
Each subscale contains 5 items rated on a 4-point scale: 1 = Very Uncertain, 2 = Rather Uncertain, 3 = Rather Certain, 4 = Very Certain. Higher scores indicate greater self-efficacy.
Example items:

Nutrition: “I can manage to stick to healthful foods …even if I need a long time to develop the necessary routines.”
Exercise: “I can manage to carry out my exercise intentions, …even when I have worries and problems.”

title: 5  Psychological Beliefs
text:
5.3 Health Information Avoidance — General

Constructs
The Health Information Avoidance Scale — General (items generated by Dr. Heather Orom, University at Buffalo) measures your tendency to seek or avoid potentially threatening information. Information avoidance reflects situations where people choose not to obtain available information, even when it is free and potentially useful.


Measures
The scale presents 7 realistic scenarios and asks whether you would want to know potentially threatening information. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale: 1 = Definitely Don’t Want to Know, 2 = Probably Don’t Want to Know, 3 = Probably Want to Know, 4 = Definitely Want to Know. Higher scores indicate less avoidance (i.e., more information-seeking).
Example item:

“You bought a phone at what seemed like a reasonable, though not particularly low, price. A month has passed… Do you want to know the price you could have bought it for?”

title: 5  Psychological Beliefs
text:
5.4 Health Information Avoidance — Depression

Constructs
The Health Information Avoidance Scale — Depression measures your tendency to avoid or seek information about a potential depression diagnosis. This scale assesses whether you would prefer to know or not know about your risk for major depression, reflecting the psychological tension between the desire for useful health information and the discomfort of receiving threatening news.


Measures
The scale contains 8 items rated on a 7-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Neutral, 5 = Slightly Agree, 6 = Agree, 7 = Strongly Agree. Items 3, 5, 7, and 8 are reverse-scored so that higher composite scores indicate more avoidance.
Example item:

“I would rather not know my risk for major depression.”

title: 6  Health Attributions & Morality
text:
6.1 Moral Foundations Questionnaire
This chapter explores your moral foundations, beliefs about the causes of mental illness, and essentialist beliefs about addiction. These constructs shape how you make moral judgments, how you attribute the causes of health and disease, and how you view people with addiction — all of which directly influence health communication strategies around tailoring, audience segmentation, and framing.

title: 6  Health Attributions & Morality
text:
Constructs
The Moral Foundations Questionnaire (MFQ; Graham et al., 2011) measures five moral foundations that underlie moral judgments across cultures:

Harm/Care: Sensitivity to suffering and cruelty; concern for the well-being of others
Fairness/Reciprocity: Concern for justice, equal treatment, and proportional outcomes
Ingroup/Loyalty: Valuing group membership, patriotism, and loyalty to one’s community
Authority/Respect: Respect for tradition, hierarchy, and social order
Purity/Sanctity: Concern about physical and spiritual purity, contamination, and disgust



Measures
The MFQ contains 22 items across two blocks: Block 1 measures moral relevance (11 items; 1 = Not at All Relevant to 5 = Extremely Relevant) and Block 2 measures moral agreement (11 items; 1 = Strongly Disagree to 6 = Strongly Agree). Each foundation is scored from 2 relevance items and 2 agreement items (after rescaling). Item 6 in each block is a catch/attention-check item and is excluded from scoring.
Example items:

Harm/Care (Relevance): “Whether or not someone suffered emotionally”
Harm/Care (Agreement): “Compassion for those who are suffering is the most crucial virtue.”

title: 6  Health Attributions & Morality
section: 6.2 Beliefs about the Causes of Mental Illness
text:
6.2 Beliefs about the Causes of Mental Illness

Constructs
The Beliefs about the Causes of Mental Illness Scale (Knettel, 2019) measures how people attribute the causes of mental illness across four categories. The scale presents a vignette about Cameron, a 30-year-old man with depression, and asks you to rate the importance of potential causes:

Social Attributions: Social injustice, lack of support, poverty, stressful circumstances, traumatic experiences
Biological Attributions: Genes, biological/medical disorder, chemical imbalance
Personal Attributions: Lack of will or self-control, personal choice, negative attitude
Lifestyle Attributions: Improper diet, exposure to germs, lack of physical activity



Measures
The scale contains 14 items rated on a 7-point scale: 1 = Not at All Important, 2 = Not Very Important, 3 = Somewhat Important, 4 = Moderately Important, 5 = Important, 6 = Significantly Important, 7 = This Cause Is Very Important. Higher scores indicate stronger attribution to that category.
Example items:

Social: “Social injustice or discrimination”
Biological: “Genes or heredity”
Personal: “Lack of will or self-control”
Lifestyle: “Improper diet”

title: 6  Health Attributions & Morality
text:
6.3 Essentialist Beliefs about Addiction

Constructs
The Essentialist Beliefs about Addiction Scale (GENBELIEFS3; 15 items) measures the extent to which you view addiction through an essentialist lens:

Categorical Thinking: Belief that people fall into discrete categories of “addict” or “non-addict,” with clear-cut boundaries and predictable traits
Biological Essentialism: Belief that addiction is genetically or biologically determined



Measures
The scale contains 15 items (11 categorical thinking, 4 biological essentialism) rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree. Higher scores indicate stronger essentialist beliefs.
Example items:

Categorical Thinking: “The boundaries that define the differences between addicts and non-addicts are clear-cut.”
Biological Essentialism: “With enough scientific knowledge, addiction can be traced back to genetic causes.”

title: 7  Sociocultural Beliefs
text:
7.1 Lay Beliefs about Competition Scale
This chapter examines your beliefs about competition, cultural orientation, and social identity perceptions. These constructs shape how you relate to others, whether you value independence or interdependence, how you view competition in society, and how you perceive the advantages and disadvantages of different social identities — all essential for designing culturally and linguistically appropriate health communication for diverse and hard-to-reach populations.

title: 7  Sociocultural Beliefs
text:
Constructs
The Lay Beliefs about Competition Scale (Murayama & Elliot, 2012) measures beliefs about the consequences of competition across two overarching dimensions:
Positive Competition Beliefs:

Performance: Belief that competition makes people work harder, perform better, and set goals
Character: Belief that competition makes people stronger, builds character, and develops self-confidence
Innovation: Belief that competition prompts new solutions, encourages innovation, and breeds imagination

Negative Competition Beliefs:

Unethical Behavior: Belief that competition leads to cheating, rule violations, and unethical behavior
Self-Harm: Belief that competition damages self-confidence, hurts self-esteem, and creates self-doubt
Social Harm: Belief that competition creates negative feelings, enemies, and divides people



Measures
The scale contains 18 items across six subscales (3 items each) rated on a 6-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Slightly Agree, 5 = Agree, 6 = Strongly Agree.
Example items:

Performance: “Competition makes people work harder”
Character: “Competition makes people stronger”
Innovation: “Competition prompts people to seek new solutions”
Unethical Behavior: “Competition leads to cheating”
Self-Harm: “Competition damages self-confidence”
Social Harm: “Competition creates negative feelings about others”

title: 7  Sociocultural Beliefs
text:
7.2 Individualism vs. Collectivism Scale

Constructs
The Individualism vs. Collectivism Scale (Triandis & Gelfand, 1998) measures four cultural orientations that combine two dimensions — independence vs. interdependence and equality vs. hierarchy:

Horizontal Individualism: Valuing independence and self-reliance without emphasis on status
Vertical Individualism: Valuing competition, status, and being better than others
Horizontal Collectivism: Valuing cooperation, sociability, and the well-being of the group
Vertical Collectivism: Valuing duty, family sacrifice, and respect for group decisions



Measures
The scale contains 16 items (4 per orientation) rated on a 9-point scale: 1 = Never or Definitely No, 9 = Always or Definitely Yes. Higher scores indicate stronger endorsement of that orientation.
Example items:

Horizontal Individualism: “I’d rather depend on myself than others.”
Vertical Individualism: “It is important that I do my job better than others.”
Horizontal Collectivism: “If a coworker gets a prize, I would feel proud.”
Vertical Collectivism: “Parents and children must stay together as much as possible.”

title: 7  Sociocultural Beliefs
text:
7.3 Social Identity Perceptions

Constructs
The Social Identity Perceptions items (GENBELIEFS4) measure how much you believe each social identity helps or hurts people’s ability to get ahead in the United States. These perceptions reflect your awareness of structural advantages and disadvantages associated with race, gender, religion, class, and nationality.


Measures
The scale contains 16 items, each rating a different social identity on a 5-point scale: 1 = Hurts a Lot, 2 = Hurts a Little, 3 = Neither Helps nor Hurts, 4 = Helps a Little, 5 = Helps a Lot.
Example item:

“Being White” — rated on how much it helps or hurts a person’s ability to get ahead in the U.S.

title: 8  Health Behaviors
text:
8.1 Social Media
This chapter examines your social media use patterns and positive health behavior profile. As health communicators, understanding your own relationship with social media — including potential problematic use — is essential for designing effective campaigns on digital platforms. Your health behaviors provide context for how lifestyle factors intersect with communication patterns.
Social media use is a critical consideration for health communicators. This section pairs two complementary measures: Social Media Addiction, which captures problematic patterns of social media engagement, and Social Media Hours, which quantifies the raw time spent on platforms each day. Together, these indicators reveal both the quantity and quality of your social media relationship.

title: 8  Health Behaviors
text:
Constructs

Social Media Addiction (adapted from the Bergen Social Media Addiction Scale; Andreassen et al., 2012): Measures problematic social media use, including interference with social life and daily activities, agitation when unable to use social media, unsuccessful attempts to reduce use, and spending more time than intended.
Social Media Hours: Self-reported daily time spent on social media platforms (hours per day).



Measures

Social Media Addiction: 5 items rated on a 7-point scale: 1 = Totally Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Neutral, 5 = Slightly Agree, 6 = Agree, 7 = Totally Agree. Higher scores indicate more problematic social media use.
Social Media Hours: A single item asking how many hours per day you spend on social media (continuous).

Example item (Addiction):

“My social life has suffered because of my interaction on social media.”

title: 8  Health Behaviors
text:
8.2 Lifestyle Health
Sleep and exercise are foundational lifestyle behaviors that directly impact physical and mental health. This section pairs Sleep (hours per night) and Exercise (days of physical activity per week) to give you a snapshot of two key health behaviors that influence energy, cognition, stress management, and overall well-being.

Constructs

Sleep: Self-reported average hours of sleep per night. Adequate sleep (typically 7–9 hours for adults) is associated with better cognitive performance, emotional regulation, and immune function.
Exercise: Self-reported number of days per week with physical activity. Regular exercise is one of the strongest predictors of both physical and mental health outcomes.



Measures

Sleep: A single item asking how many hours of sleep you typically get per night (continuous).
Exercise: A single item asking how many days per week you engage in physical activity (0–7 days).

title: 8  Health Behaviors
text:
8.3 Mental Health
Stress and life satisfaction are complementary indicators of mental well-being. Stress captures the burden of daily pressures, while Life Satisfaction reflects a broader cognitive evaluation of how well life is going. These two measures often move in opposite directions — higher stress tends to accompany lower life satisfaction — and together they provide a more complete picture of your psychological health.

Constructs

Stress: Self-reported stress level on a 0–10 scale. Higher scores indicate greater perceived stress.
Life Satisfaction: Overall satisfaction with life, reflecting a global cognitive judgment about one’s quality of life.



Measures

Stress: A single item rated from 0 = No Stress to 10 = Extreme Stress.
Life Satisfaction: A single item rated on a 6-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree to 6 = Strongly Agree.

title: 8  Health Behaviors
text:
8.4 Subjective Health
Subjective health assessments capture how you perceive your own physical and mental health overall. Health Status and Mental Health Status are widely used single-item measures in public health research because they are strong predictors of objective health outcomes, healthcare utilization, and mortality. These self-ratings reflect an integrated judgment that incorporates factors you may not consciously articulate.

Constructs

Health Status: Self-rated overall physical health, ranging from Poor to Excellent.
Mental Health Status: Self-rated overall mental health, ranging from Poor to Excellent.



Measures

Health Status: A single item rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Poor, 2 = Fair, 3 = Good, 4 = Very Good, 5 = Excellent.
Mental Health Status: A single item rated on a 5-point scale: 1 = Poor, 2 = Fair, 3 = Good, 4 = Very Good, 5 = Excellent.

title: 9  Economic/Commercial Beliefs
text:
9.1 Perceived vs. Desired Wealth Distribution
This chapter explores your beliefs about wealth distribution, zero-sum thinking, and beliefs about commercial determinants of health. These constructs are critical for health communication because they shape how people understand systemic causes of health inequities, whether they view social progress as a competition, and how they perceive corporate influence on public health.

title: 9  Economic/Commercial Beliefs
text:
Constructs
These items (adapted from Norton & Ariely, 2011) measure perceptions and preferences about how wealth is distributed in the United States. Perceived wealth distribution captures what you think the current distribution is, while desired wealth distribution captures what you believe would be fair. Comparing these to the actual distribution reveals how well-calibrated people’s perceptions are and how much redistribution they prefer.


Measures
Each distribution allocates 100% of total wealth across five quintiles (Top 20% through Bottom 20%). Participants estimated both their perceived and desired distributions. The chart below compares three distributions: Perceived (participant estimates), Desired (participant ideals), and Actual (Federal Reserve data).

title: 9  Economic/Commercial Beliefs
text:
9.2 Zero-Sum Beliefs

Constructs
The Zero-Sum Beliefs Scale (OPINIONBELIEFS) measures the extent to which you believe that gains for one group necessarily come at the expense of another group:

Economic Zero-Sum: Belief that economic gains are always at someone else’s loss
Social Identity Zero-Sum: Belief that progress for marginalized groups comes at the expense of dominant groups (e.g., less sexism for women means more sexism for men)



Measures
The scale contains 11 items (3 economic, 8 social identity) rated on a 7-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disbelieve, 2 = Somewhat Disbelieve, 3 = Disbelieve, 4 = Neither Disbelieve nor Believe, 5 = Believe, 6 = Somewhat Believe, 7 = Strongly Believe. Higher scores indicate stronger zero-sum thinking.
Example items:

Economic: “Life is so devised that when somebody gains, others have to lose.”
Social Identity: “As women face less sexism, men end up facing more sexism.”

title: 9  Economic/Commercial Beliefs
text:
9.3 Commercial Determinants of Health (CDOH) Beliefs

Constructs
The CDOH Beliefs Scale measures beliefs about how three industries negatively influence public health through political lobbying, research distortion, marketing practices, distribution inequities, labor practices, pricing, and community power:

Firearms Industry: Beliefs about gun industry influence on legislation, research, marketing, distribution, labor, pricing, and community health
Food Industry: Beliefs about food industry influence on nutrition policy, research, marketing, food access, labor, pricing, and local food systems
Healthcare Industry: Beliefs about healthcare/pharmaceutical industry influence on mental health policy, research, marketing, distribution, labor, pricing, and access



Measures
The scale contains 21 items (7 per industry) rated on a 6-point scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Slightly Disagree, 4 = Slightly Agree, 5 = Agree, 6 = Strongly Agree. Higher scores indicate stronger belief in corporate influence on health.
Example items:

Firearms: “The firearm industry’s lobbying prevents passage of evidence-based gun safety legislation”
Food: “Food industry political influence blocks regulations that could improve food security”
Healthcare: “Healthcare companies’ political power restricts access to mental health services”

10.3 AI Acknowledgment
Claude AI (Anthropic) was used in the development of this guide. All content was reviewed, edited, and approved by the authors.
